Comment: This was, I think, the second game between me and dmaestro.  He won the first, which arose from a debate about an annotated game.  As is my custom, I bow to his higher grade by opening with 1. d4.
and he responds with my own favourite ...
but this is different.  A flexible move that could lead to any number of continuations.
but this is different.  A flexible move that could lead to any number of continuations.
The Old Indian.  As its name suggests, hardly the height of fashion but a sound opening with counter-attacking possibilities.
The Old Indian.  As its name suggests, hardly the height of fashion but a sound opening with counter-attacking possibilities.

So far, all perfectly logical, and we're still in the database.  This move is by no means obvious but it's probably preferable to any other moves available at the time.  The main purpose is to contest the d-file, supporting d4 and establishing a longer term threat against Black's Q...

so Black sidesteps immediately with a natural developing move.
gaining space at the expense of releasing some tension
Black avoids opening the c-file, apparently planning to adopt a conventional King's Indian formation.
Preparing White's next move by preventing ... Ng4
preparing ... Nf4 and ... f5
preparing ... Nf4 and ... f5
preparing ... Nf4 and ... f5
discouraging ... Nf4
revealing an attack on the weakened h-pawn
unexpected but logical, as it further supports ... f5 and the N was no longer usefully employed on h5
unexpected but logical, as it further supports ... f5 and the N was no longer usefully employed on h5
A typical thrust by White in Indian-style positions, dislodging Black's most forward piece
A sign that I'm running out of ideas at this point.  This B doesn't attack anythingbut does take temporary control fo d8, where I suspected that Black would want to place his R or Q in due course.
A sign that I'm running out of ideas at this point.  This B doesn't attack anythingbut does take temporary control fo d8, where I suspected that Black would want to place his R or Q in due course.
Ntuarally Black pushes the intruder away.

Retreating my B a further square to d2 as I intend reposting my R on e1 and I don't want it to be obstructing the defence of e4.  I'm conscious at this stage of the game of trying not to give Black any opportunities.

Freeing up the Bc8, though its only square is d7, so it's not much freedom.  This will, in turn connect Black's Rooks, though, so it's still worthwhile.  The N also builds prssure on d5 and c4, though it doesn't actually threaten either pawn as yet.
Expanding on the Q-side and threatening to shift the N

Finally, Black "cracks" and releases the tension in the centre.  This exchange is well timed as White has to be careful about potential pins on the c-file and also about releasing Black's e-pawn, which could disrupt White's position if it advanced.
